## Worksheets

I teach Computer Systems and Assembly language using fill-in-the-blank
worksheets that I’ve designed. Students who manually write out notes
are more likely to retain information presented in class over students
who type notes.

These worksheets allows students to handwrite notes and follow along in
class, without getting overwhelmed with feeling like they need to write
everything. I include examples for students to work out both during
lecture with their classmates, and outside of class.

html_parts = []

for r in rows:

  supplement_list: str = ''

  if (r['supplement'] != []):

    supplement_list: str = '<p><strong>SUPPLEMENTS</strong></br>'

    # Construct list of supplemental materials.
    for i in range(len(r['supplement'])):
      sup: dict = r['supplement']

      supplement_list = supplement_list +\
        f' <a href="{sup[i]['link']}">{sup[i]['desc']}</a>'

      supplement_list = supplement_list + '</p>'

  html_parts.append(f"""
<details><summary><strong>{r['heading']}</strong></summary>
  </br>
  <p><a href="{r['worksheet']}"><strong>WORKSHEET</strong></a></p>
  <p>{r['desc']}</p>
  {supplement_list}
  </br>
</details>
""")

# join and display as raw HTML so Quarto renders it as actual collapsible sections
display(HTML("".join(html_parts)))
